{% endraw %}

Matrix multiplication

Check here for the matrix multiplication vizualization

{% raw %} 
def matmul(a, b):
    ar, ac = a.shape
    br, bc = b.shape
    assert ac == br
    c = torch.zeros(ar, bc)
    for i in range(ar):
        for j in range(bc):
            for k in range(ac):
                c[i][j] += a[i,k]*b[k,j]
    return c
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
m1 = x_valid[:5];
m2 = weights
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
m1.shape, m2.shape

(torch.Size([5, 784]), torch.Size([784, 10]))
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

Elementwise operations

{% raw %} 
def matmul(a, b):
    ar, ac = a.shape
    br, bc = b.shape
    assert ac == br
    c = torch.zeros(ar, bc)
    for i in range(ar):
        for j in range(bc):
            c[i][j] = (a[i,:]*b[:,j]).sum()
    return c
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
%timeit -n 10 _= matmul(m1, m2)

1.42 ms ± 45.9 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test_close(t1, matmul(m1,m2))
{% endraw %}

Broadcasting

{% raw %} 
def matmul(a, b):
    ar, ac = a.shape
    br, bc = b.shape
    assert ac == br
    c = torch.zeros(ar, bc)
    for i in range(ar):
            '''
            c[i] = (a[i].unsqueeze(-1) * b).sum(dim=0) OR
            '''
            c[i] = (a[i, :, None] * b).sum(dim=0)
    return c
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
%timeit -n 10 _= matmul(m1, m2)

299 µs ± 40.5 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each)
{% endraw %}

Einstein summation

{% raw %} 
def matmul(a, b): return torch.einsum('ik,kj->ij', a, b)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
%timeit -n 10 _=matmul(m1, m2)

82.6 µs ± 31.2 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each)
{% endraw %}

pytorch op

{% raw %} 
%timeit -n 10 t2 = m1.matmul(m2)

The slowest run took 6.51 times longer than the fastest. This could mean that an intermediate result is being cached.
23.6 µs ± 21.6 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
# time comparison vs pure python

t2 = m1@m2
